entry.title: Introduction to my explorations of offgrid living

link.title: Introduction to my explorations of offgrid living

entry.content:
offgrid living, which used to be arduous and uncomfortable, is worth reviving with modern technology.

Despite urbanization being the proven way to economic prosperity and life quality, it has hit bottlenecks in almost all the developed world.

Advantages of offgrid living

  • Economic freedom.

    Offgrid living is simple and cheap, allowing offgriders to live with relatively shorter work hours, so in case the work is not fulfilling, there could be more time for self actualization.

  • Environment friendly.

    With biomass and solar panels as energy source, offgrid homes use much less fossil energy than urban homes.

  • Escape from high crime areas.

    Keeping urban communities safe is a more complex task compared to rural communties. Many cities are ill managed.

  • Hedging against unaffordle home prices.

    Even for urban dwellers, having the choice of moving to an offgrid location improve their negotiation position.

  • Exploring the wilderland.

    It’s part of human nature and enjoyment.

  • Disaster Preparedness.

    Grid could be offline under a major disaster such as earthquake, terrorist attack and nuclear war.

Challenges of offgrid living

  • Transportation — transit and cargo
  • Energy — electricity and fuel
  • Heating and cooling — living in comfortable temperature
  • Water — tap water and wastewater
  • Telecom — internet and phone

My case studies

Urban housing is industrial, commercial and standard. Offgrid housing is natural, diverse and adaptive. Offgrid living space must be designed according to the climate, resources and infrastructure of the location.

Offgrid living is better studied through cases, for which I have considered 3:

  • Mojave Desert
  • Saskatchewan Priaries
  • Small van/RV on urban lot

On water saving and reusing in arid areas

Many arid areas have limited precipitation, making rain water impossible to rely on. Water has to be trucked into offgrid homes.

The only feasible way is extreme water saving.

According to EPA,

Toilet, Shower, Faucet, Clothes Washer, Leak are five main categories of water usage.

Toilet

  • Incineration toilets don’t use water, but electric heat to break down and gasify human waste.
  • Outhouses can be located a distance from main residence, and use solar heat to desiccate human waste into combustible “dung cakes” that can be augered into a fuel container.
  • All heat-based waterless toilets require tall flue pipe to discharge smelly exhaust.

Shower

Shower water can be filtered and recirculated for many times, until it’s too soapy for showering.

Hand washing

Similar but easier than shower, a basin of water for hand washing can be kept for a long time, with bariostatic agents such as benzyl alcohol.

Dishwasher

Dishwashers can recirculate the cleaning agent in a closed loop. White vinegar is a good cleaning agent for its cleaning power and antiseptic, properties. Filters can be used to catch the food debris for periodic removal.

Solar distilling

Water saturated with impurities and soap can be solar distilled. In order to keep distilled water scentless, scentless detergents and shampoos should be used in kitchen and bathroom.
entry.summary: offgrid living, which used to be arduous and uncomfortable, is worth reviving with modern technology.

entry.title: Serving tastier coffee for food vendors, with simple utensils

link.title: Serving tastier coffee for food vendors, with simple utensils

entry.content:
serving tasty coffee in commercial settings by mixing chilled airtight concentrate with water.

In coffee shops, fast food restaurants and gas stations, coffee is usually served by dripping a big kettle with a commercial-sized coffee machine, kept hot and served to upcoming customer by cups.

Whether kept hot or not, the coffee loses flavor soon after being brewed, resulting in either degraded taste or waste of coffee.

As a coffee enthusiastic, I developed a better way of commercially serving coffee, inspired by discussion with a friend who is a coffee shop barista.

The method

brew (-> chill) -> filter -> dilute

Things

  • French press
  • thin wall aluminum bottle with cap
  • ice bucket, bottle can fully immerse in which
  • stainless mesh pour over filter
  • foil-spouted liquid pouch
  • spigot that fits the pouch
  • distilled water
  • Coffee ground or beans in airtight inert gas filled packets

Procedure

  • Brew: instead of brewing “regular coffee”, use french press to brew a coffee concentrate as intense as espresso. Add 1 volume of distilled water per 1 volume of loose coffee ground. Cold brew(4°C water) for 6 hours, or hot brew(80°C) for 3 minutes.

  • Chill: If hot brew, transfer the hot concentrate into a clean thin wall aluminum bottle (soda/beer aluminum bottles can be reused), close the cap and immediately immerse the bottle in ice-water mixture. If the bottle is large, shake the bottle to assist convection inside bottle.

  • Filter: A french press will leave some fine solids in coffee. Filter them out with a stainless mesh pour over filter. Do not use paper filter because paper absorbs some flavor.

    • Store the filtered concentrate away from light and air, e.g. in a foil-spouted liquid pouch. Screw in a spigot onto the pouch for dispensing.

    • The coffee concentrate is good for at least 24 hours.

  • Dilute: before serving to customers, dilute the concentrate with hot/cold water as hot/cold coffee. Concentrate:water 1:3 - 1:5

Simple chemistry explanation

Coffee flavor are natural antioxidants, i.e. active reducing agents. When it reacts with oxygen, the aroma is lost, and the taste become bitter and sour. Some flavor substances reacts with oxygen in dry air, others reacts with oxygen dissolved in water.

Temperature, light and metal ions in water may accelerate these reactions.

It’s why commercial coffee grounds are packed by individual inert gas filled bags, which prevent flavor from being oxidized.

It’s why hot brewed coffee loses taste after a few hours, but cold brewed coffee lasts a bit longer.

By storing the concentrate cold and airtight, the flavor last longer before serving.

Automating coffee making for food vendors

This process involves more dedications than the traditional method, but it can be easily automated by volumetric dispensing pumps controlled by relays and a computer, to the level of unattended serving ready-to-drink coffee to customers.

If interested, contact me for implementation.
entry.summary: serving tasty coffee in commercial settings by mixing chilled airtight concentrate with water.

entry.title: nCharIndex for speeding up SQL substring match queries

link.title: nCharIndex for speeding up SQL substring match queries

entry.content:
index with short(2-3) substrings can greatly reduce search domain of substring matches for SQL LIKE queries, resulting in 150-300x acceleration

Background

nCharIndex is my customized solution for a client’s string database that handles many partial match analytical queries like the following:

select ... from SOME_TABLE as T where T.textfield like “%o9tyqy4%bdEAS”

The tables are terabytes huge, and the text field values are long strings. The values are neither natural language words nor delimited by any characters.

These queries take several minutes and even hours to complete, quite disruptive to their workflow.

Fulltext and document indexes of common RDBMS like Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL and PostgresSQL do not accelerate this sort of query, because they are word-based optimized for natural language text and webpages. The client have tried Lucene, but the performance is as limited as MySQL. We have not found solutions during our survey of non-RDBMS database systems like Redis, Mongodb and Cassandra.

How it works

nCharIndex stores the mapping between all n-length substrings of the indexed field values to the primary keys (id) of their rows.

While queried with a match pattern no shorter than n, we retrieve the id sets of all n-length substrings of the set. We intersect all the id sets together, to have a much smaller candidate id superset of possible matches.

This candidate superset of ids is then joined with the original SQL pattern matching (LIKE) query, so the RDBMS will only look up in the candidate id set, greatly reducing the number of iterations.

Example

Indexing

id textfield length 3 substrings
0 cat cat
1 dog dog
2 cater cat,ate,ter
3 dogma dog,ogm,gma
4 dogma_cater dog,ogm,gma,ma_,a_c,cat,ate,ter

TABLE1

Let n=3. The length 3 substrings of the textfield are listed as above. Our index is a mapping from length-3 substrings to set of row ids with this substring:

substr set of row id
cat 0,2,4
dog 1,3,4
ate 2,4
ter 2,4
ogm 3,4
gma 3,4
ma_ 4
a_c 4

Querying

Case 1: select * from TABLE1 where textfield like "%dogma%"

If a string have a substring “dogma”, it must have length-3 sub strings: “dog”, “ogm” and “gma”, but not vice versa (e.g. “dogogmgma” have all these substrings, but “dogma” is not its substring).

Thus, we find their corresponding row id sets {1,3,4}, {3,4} and {3,4}, whose intersection is {3, 4}, which is stored into a RDBMS temporary table “substr_index_matches”, as below:

id
3
4

and the query is transformed into:

select * from substr_index_matches m join TABLE1 t on m.id=t.id and textfield like “%dogma%”

The query saves time because it only pattern match 2 text fields instead of 5.

Implementation note: on MySQL, we can also use straight_join to always join on the first condition (m.id=t.id).

Case 2: select * from TABLE1 where textfield like "%at%"

Because “at” is shorter than 3, we need to find all length-3 substrings containing “at”, which are “cat” and “ate” , with index sets {0,2,4} and {2,4}

Instead of intersecting their corresponding row id sets, we union these sets to directly produce the result: {0,2,4}, without having to invoke the RDBMS query to confirm the have substring “at”.

Implementation and Performance

Querying

The published code is implemented in C++, with rocksdb as key-value storage backend for storing the mapping from length-n substrings to row id sets, and “hps” library for serialization. MySQLx C++ API is called for querying the local MySQL server.

The performance improvement is very significant, with affordable cost of index space.

Performance of raw RDBMS query vs ncharIndex-assisted query depend primarily on the cardinality of result. The acceleration ratio is higher for match patterns with fewer occurrences in the string database. The length of match patterns also matters to a lesser degree.

I tested the index query speed using imdb database’s movie_info table as a surrogate to the production database, and used top-1000 frequent words from a English language statistics website. Acceleration is significant at about 300x.

Building

If the index is a N-char index(optimal value of N is 2 or 3 depending on the text), for a text database with n rows and average text length m and alphabet size A, there will be:

  • AN index entries
  • Average m-N+1 substrings for each row (with possible duplicates)

Without considering the duplicates, theoretically the time and space usage of index building is O(AN+nm), however, simulated data tests reveal that N=3 costs 2-6 times more time and 2-3 times more space than N=2.

As N=2 is sufficient for most text databases, I recommend use N=2 unless a higher N is proven more effective.

For comparison of index build and access performance, I also incompletely implemented another version utilizing LLNL metall as the persistence backend. LLNL metall is a memory allocator library that allocates on memory mapped(mmap) files, with interface for boost template containers. The performance advantage to the rocksdb version is significant.

See detailed analysis, on this page
entry.summary: index with short(2-3) substrings can greatly reduce search domain of substring matches for SQL LIKE queries, resulting in 150-300x acceleration

entry.title: nCharIndex performance experiment
entry.summary: comparison of query and build time between nCharIndex and non-indexed MySQL

entry.title: Python profiling and performance optimization by foreign calls

link.title: Python profiling and performance optimization by foreign calls

entry.content:
Explains my practices and concerns in optimizing the performance of python code.

Move fast and break things. Python is the language choice for rapid iteration and prototyping. When the code eventually mature, sometimes performance becomes the next thing to work on.

A few steps before doing code optimization:

  1. Look for mature high performance libraries, such as numpy, scipy and google or-tools, for the heavy crunches. They usually have highly optimized kernels written in C/Fortran. However, a seasoned developer probably already know and employ these libraries, because they make the coding quicker and the code cleaner, so our innovative algorithms are already in the no-lib-land.

  2. Try various static and JIT compilers as drop-in replacement for CPython intepreter, such as Cython, Numba and PyPy. Usually, these compilers significantly improve performance for a few lines of code rewriting. Note: PyPy is fast by itself, but incompatible with many high performance libraries.

  3. Upgrading hardware. Hardware is cheaper than developer time. Nevertheless, before spending money and man-hour on hardware, try the program on any cloud provider’s higher end cloud units to evaluate performance improvements. In many cases, a higher end server only marginally improve performance, because the critical section would not use additional resources.

After doing the above, if the performance is still insufficient, we continue with the following brain stretching optimization steps.

Finding the bottleneck

90% of performance improvement are found by optimizing 10% of code. The numbers could be 80:20 or 99:1, nevertheless we need to find the hot sections before doing any meaningful optimization. There are two approches.

Static analysis

The time complexity of each part can be statically derived by looking at the code. For example, there could be obviously O(1), O(n) and O(n2) part of the code, and from the libraries documents we know the cost of library function calls. These part with higher asymptotic complexity can be singled out for optimization.

Static analysis does not always find the culprit, because there are hidden overheads, such as function call, memory allocation, object creation and exception handling overheads that break asymptotic analysis, which can be found in profiling.

Profiling

Profiling is a different approach – it measures time spent in each part of the program in test runs. Profiles such as python’s profile and cProfile can be used to gather a profile log, and visualizers like SnakeViz display the profile log in more obvious ways.

Because we cannot profile on every possible input, we profile on typical inputs and practically worst case inputs.

Optimizing against the bottleneck

A bottleneck is usually a block of code (a loop or a function). We begin by writing down on paper a description of what the block does and all its inputs. Hopefully there are obvious easy ways to improve it.

There could be no easy ways to improve it, or the easy ways does not provide enough squeeze, which is actually quite common since we tend to have written crappy code for rapid iteration, and CPython is anyway not a platform for high performance.

Our efforts are not wasted, because we can refactor and outsource the bottleneck to a higher performance platform, such as C++/C/Java, to reduce at least the constant factor.

Comments on higher performance platforms

C++/C/Java are only platforms, not magic bullets. They rely on understanding and requires some manual calibration. A program could be slow even it’s written in C, plus the drawback of maintenability.

Keep complexity and dependency at minimum. The complexity involves complexity of the algorithm itself and complexity of interoperation.

Do not underestimate the complexity, as every programming language has specific data types, calling conventions and compile/link mechanisms, that often don’t interact. It’s probably not a problem for numpy developers, but a big headache for most programmers.

The complexity is aggravated by the fact that a developer is usually good at one language. We can make another developer code the non-python part, yet the gateway between both codes has to be maintained by both developers together. The collaboration overhead is not trivial.

Ways to call foreign code from Python

Here is a list of ways of calling C(C++/Java) functions from python, ranked by complexity. Again, use the

  • subprocess invokes passing arguments by command line and files in temporary path
  • local interprocess mechanisms (pipes, named pipes, shared memory mapping)
  • RPC frameworks, such as gRPC and Thrift
  • foreign language interfaces (Python.h, cffi, ctypes, pybind11, cython, py4j) that have object-level access to foreign program

Simplify foreign code

  • Preprocess data in python.The foreign code should have as few lines as possible for preprocessing data.
  • Strip irrelevant data and simplify data structure.The input data should contain as little irrelevant information as possible. It is usually worthy to strip irrelevant data and transform data structure to the simplist possible in Python as the input of the foreign function, because
  • Use a common serialization/deserialization scheme for custom data structure.

Toy Example: Dijkstra-like function

The original code is written by a student for the “minimum effort” programming challenge. The code is correct, yet inconsiderate of performance. It “abuses” python containers for set semantics, it fails to use the proven priority queue data structure to hold intermediate result, etc. We will demostrate its bottleneck by profiling.

The original programming question is similar but different to shortest path, that we cannot simply call an existing shortest path library function. Thus, the strategy is to grab some proven Dijkstra code and modify it for our purpose.

We improved performance by 115x just by optimized data structure using pure python, and 2818x using python calling C++ subroutine with ctypes. Click here for details in a separate page.
entry.summary: Explains my practices and concerns in optimizing the performance of python code.

entry.title: On fairness of wireless channel allocation/contention schemes

link.title: On fairness of wireless channel allocation/contention schemes

entry.content:
what does fairness mean in allocating channel to interfering nodes On fairness of a channel allocation or contention scheme

Please view this page in Firefox if math equation format is messed up

Single channel allocation

suppose the set of all nodes who need to use a single channel resource is V, their interference graph is (V,E), E={(i,j)|i, j ∈ V using the same channel interfere with each other}
  • each valid allocation is a Maximal Independent Set (MaxIS) of (V,E), denoted here by lower case letter s .
  • the set of all valid allocations of (V,E) to be denoted S = { s 1 , s 2 ... s m } .
  • a single channel allocation scheme has a probability mass function for a probability distribution on S : p 1 , p 2 , … , p m , ∑ i=1 m p i =1 , and ∀ i : p i ⩾ 0 is probability to choose the i th allocation.

Fairness Condition

the condition that a random channel allocation scheme is "fair":
∀ j ∈ V: ∑ i:j ∈ s i p i = 1 | V |
∑ i=1 m p i =1
We can see this is a linear system for { p 1 , p 2 , … , p m } with | V | +1 equations and m variables ( p 1 , p 2 , … , p m ). Depending on the interference graph, the linear system either:
  1. Has no non-negative solution of { p 1 , p 2 , … , p m } .
    This happens in two cases:
    (1) Has no solution of { p 1 , p 2 , … , p m }
    (2) Has real number solution of { p 1 , p 2 , … , p m } , but at least one of { p 1 , p 2 , … , p m } is negative.
  2. Has only one non-negative solution of { p 1 , p 2 , … , p m } .
  3. Has infinitely many solutions of { p 1 , p 2 , … , p m } .
A standard linear systems solver can easily decide which case applies from those 3, given the equations.

Fair allocations usually don't maximize throughput

The highest throughput is acquired by always allocating the channel to the largest MaxIS.
Thus, except uncommon cases like fully connected or null interference graph, or a graph with high symmetry among nodes, fair allocations don't maximize throughput.
entry.summary: what does fairness mean in allocating channel to interfering nodes
